review.title: Prognostics of Surgical Site Infections using Dynamic Health Data
review.abstract: Surgical Site Infection (SSI) is a national priority in healthcare research. Much research attention has been attracted to develop better SSI risk prediction models. However, most of the existing SSI risk prediction models are built on static risk factors such as comorbidities and operative factors. In this paper, we investigate the use of the dynamic wound data for SSI risk prediction. There have been emerging mobile health (mHealth) tools that can closely monitor the patients and generate continuous measurements of many wound-related variables and other evolving clinical variables. Since existing prediction models of SSI have quite limited capacity to utilize the evolving clinical data, we develop the corresponding solution to equip these mHealth tools with decision-making capabilities for SSI prediction with a seamless assembly of several machine learning models to tackle the analytic challenges arising from the spatial-temporal data. The basic idea is to exploit the low-rank property of the spatial-temporal data via the bilinear formulation, and further enhance it with automatic missing data imputation by the matrix completion technique. We derive efficient optimization algorithms to implement these models and demonstrate the superior performances of our new predictive model on a real-world dataset of SSI, compared to a range of state-of-the-art methods.

In this paper, we examine the use of dynamic wound data for SSI risk forecasting. As existing SSI prediction models have fairly limited capacity to utilize the evolving clinical data, we are developing the appropriate solution to equip these mHealth tools with decision-making capabilities for SSI forecasting, with a seamless assembly of multiple machine learning challenges emerging from the learning environment.

sections.heading: 3.1. An Overview of the Proposed Machine Learning System
sections.text: The overall goal of the proposed machine learning system is to predict the time until the start of SSI using spatio-temporal matrix data. There are several major data challenges that need to be overcome, such as the merging of complete samples and censored samples, missing values in spatio-temporal matrices, and the complex reciprocal interaction structure of spatio-temporal matrices. To mitigate these challenges, Figure 2 illustrates an overall scheme of the proposed machine learning system. It consists of a novel modeling formulation to merge both complete samples and censored samples, using limited matrix completion to mitigate the missing data problem. In addition, the learning formulation is equipped with model regularization techniques such as image-based formalism and sparse learning to mitigate the challenges posed by the high dimensionality of the spatio-temporal matrix and the use of its intemporal and spatial structure.

sections.heading: 3.5. Bounded Matrix Completion (BMC)
sections.text: In this section, we will develop a matrix completion approach to mitigate the problem of missing data in our problem. Missing data has been ubiquitous in many healthcare applications. We found no exception in our study, as data is collected from patients and compliance with data collection is always a challenge for many reasons. We propose to use the matrix completion approach to fill in the missing values rather than using simple heuristic approaches, such as using averages to replace the missing values. Our reasoning, again, is that the correlations in the spatio-time matrix essentially imply that the spatio-time matrix is low. For example, some variables used to measure the wound could be correlated, such as the color and temperature of the wound. Due to this reason, by using their correlations, we could recover many missing values as long as we have observed some values in the matrix, in order to take advantage of this idea that there are some mental factors related to the individual observation there.

sections.heading: 4.1. Study population
sections.text: A prospective cohort study of 1,000 patients with open abdominal surgery was conducted in an academic teaching hospital with 1200 beds in the Netherlands previously described [30]. Patients who did not undergo surgery (n = 33) or with < 2 days of wound observation (n = 107) were excluded from the analysis, resulting in a total of 860 patients being affected. Subjects were prospectively examined for CDC-defined superficial, deep and / or organ space infections [9]. Surface SSI infections are infections that occur within 30 days of surgery and which affect only skin or subcutaneous tissue of the incision and at least one of the following: 1) discharge from the incision, with or without confirmation by laboratory tests; 2) organisms that are isolated from an aseptic culture or aspiration of the incision; 3) at least one of the following signs or subcutaneous tissue of the incision and symptoms: an infection or redness, or sensitivity, or a facial infection; 3) at least one of the following signs or subcutaneous tissue of the incision or symptoms is present; 3) an infection or a recurrent infection, or a recurrence, or sensitivity, or a recurrence, or a recurrence, or a recurrence, or a recurrence, or a recurrence, or a recurrence of an infection.

sections.heading: 4.5. Evaluation of the matrix completion method for missing data imputation
sections.text: Furthermore, we evaluate the performance of the matrix completion method for missing data imputation compared to other methods. For example, the "column mean" method to supplement the missing value on characteristic j of the individual i at a given time may use the mean value of characteristic j of all individuals over all time points based on the observed measurements. Other methods we use for comparison include the K-NearestNeighbor (KNN) method, which is widely used for missing data imputation [34, 35] and a more recent Bayesian approach [36]. We train the models using various methods to import missing data at different values of λ and report the results, as shown in Figure 6. It clearly shows that our low-level matrix completion method could lead to superior performance in missing data imputation, thereby achieving better predictive performance of the model.

sections.heading: 4.6. Optimal configuration of the proposed learning system
sections.text: In order to determine the optimal configuration of the proposed learning system, we build a sequence of models to examine the performance of different configurations. Among these critical parameters, the duration of the dynamic data that we could use to build the predictive model, the rank of the model parameters w and the value of λ. Among these parameters, the duration of the dynamic data is probably the most important parameter. Obviously, there is a trade-off between accuracy and cost. In the longer term, more information could be collected that will lead to better predictive accuracy. On the other hand, it will lead to higher costs, not only in data collection, but also in health costs due to the potential delay in the identification of patients who will soon develop SSI. Therefore, it is a practical and important decision to find an appropriate length for observation and prediction. metadata.abstractText: Surgical Site Infection (SSI) is a national priority in healthcare research. Much research attention has been attracted to develop better SSI risk prediction models. However, most of the existing SSI risk prediction models are built on static risk factors such as comorbidities and operative factors. In this paper, we investigate the use of the dynamic wound data for SSI risk prediction. There have been emerging mobile health (mHealth) tools that can closely monitor the patients and generate continuous measurements of many wound-related variables and other evolving clinical variables. Since existing prediction models of SSI have quite limited capacity to utilize the evolving clinical data, we develop the corresponding solution to equip these mHealth tools with decision-making capabilities for SSI prediction with a seamless assembly of several machine learning models to tackle the analytic challenges arising from the spatial-temporal data. The basic idea is to exploit the low-rank property of the spatial-temporal data via the bilinear formulation, and further enhance it with automatic missing data imputation by the matrix completion technique. We derive efficient optimization algorithms to implement these models and demonstrate the superior performances of our new predictive model on a real-world dataset of SSI, compared to a range of state-of-the-art methods.
